thread.title: Call for 16 and 17-year-olds to be given their say in Brexit 'People's Vote'

author: Simon Meechan
title: Call for 16 and 17-year-olds to be given their say in Brexit 'People's Vote'
text:

Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable has called for 16 and 17-year-olds to be allowed to have their say in any 'People's Vote' on the Brexit deal.
The Twickenham MP was in Newcastle on Saturday, where he spoke to protesters to demand a People's Vote on the terms agreed ahead of Britain leaving the European Union .
Mr Cable said the 2016 vote to leave was "imposed on young people to the loss of their futures"
He said: "What I want to see when we have this People's Vote is that 16 and 17 year olds are allowed to take part."
He added: "We’ve got to win the argument now for having the People’s Vote. Some people will say it’s all in vain. It’s not too late, there is still time. Supporters of the People's Vote campaign gather at The Assembly Rooms, Newcastle, to watch speeches by politicians in eluding Vince Cable (Image: Staff)
"The biggest lesson we need to learn is that very often a whole generation imposes it’s preferences on young people. So what we want to see if we get this People’s Vote is that 16 and 17-year-olds get voting.
"This is a campaign we are winning. We can win and we will win." Read More Brexit called Britain's 'biggest economic and social disaster' at Newcastle rally
Neither Labour or the Conservatives officially back a plan for a second referendum, though MPs from both sides have called for it. Redcar MP Anna Turley was one of several speakers who joined Mr Cable in Newcastle to call for a second vote.
On Tuesday, Labour shadow minister Barry Gardiner warned civil disobedience and social disruption could emerge if a second EU referendum was held, and said the result of the 2016 vote should be respected.
The UK is scheduled to leave the EU on March 29, 2019. Like us on Facebook
